page.title: 08Clatto (continued)
page.content: When parties go to the Water Services Laboratories at{Clatto,}the station superintendant explains how the system works. The water supply for the whole of Dundee is purified there but the water is no longer supplied from {Clatto Reservoir}as you might expect, but from the Backwater Dam and from Lintrathen Reservoir, both of which are many miles from the city. Clatto is held in reserve just in case the city needs extra supply. The treatment plant was opened in 1972 and has a 20 million gallon capacity through two 6 million gallon tanks. Water is even pumped across the River Tay to Fife through pipes which run under the road and rail bridges. The water reaches the plant in a fairly clean condition only needing filtered to clear all traces of peat and soil. It is then purified by chlorine to kill bacteria.
